ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: All lectures were recorded and it was possible to watch them afterwards.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A summary of software verification techniques, including theory and practical applications. We had several programming assignments in which we implemented the algorithms and ideas we learned about in class.
Basic knowledge of a variety of the techniques used in formal software verification, as well as practical knowledge of their construction and use.
I learnt about different techniques in formal software verification.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The programming assignments were well-designed and were a great way for me to engage with the material and understand the concepts from class. The written assignments were also helpful. The lectures were generally well-organized and easy to follow with plenty of opportunities for discussion and questions when something wasn't clear.
Course is rather slow -- could go faster. Less time on basic logic would be helpful. Material, apart from those basics, is interested and varied -- good survey of the field.

Strengths: Professor Piskac is a pretty great lecturer and is clearly passionate about the subject. Both the professor and TA were readily available to answer questions and meet over Zoom.

Weaknesses: More work that I anticipated. We had 6 hw assignments (which is the total workload of some other CS classes) along with 4 coding projects, at least 2 of which were quite a bit of work.
The assignments were vey interesting, and thanks to homework problem sets I did not fall behind on other material.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The virtual lectures were well-run with sufficient opportunities to interrupt with questions/discussion.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if you're interested in verification techniques.
Yes -- software verification is a really interesting topic that you might not sadly not encounter much outside academia.
